content.brief: Our work force is the first line of defense in protecting the People’s information. We will foster a culture where every employee, from average employee to system administrator, recognizes their critical role in the protecting the People’s information in the cyber risk management construct, and shares information on a continual basis to address new and emerging cyber threats. We will continue to invest in timely and focused cyber awareness training and ensure access to the right education to execute their responsibilities. We will hire high quality and talented individuals, compensate them fairly, and provide them with advancement opportunities. We will expand the pipeline of skilled cybersecurity talent for the Government and beyond through efforts targeted at education at all levels.

Information is a critical asset and the United States Government and its employees are the custodians of the People’s information. America’s information must be handled appropriately to ensure its integrity, confidentiality, and availability are appropriately managed in a fiscally-responsible manner. We will protect the People’s information based on its classification, sensitivity, and value. We will continue to align our cyber defenses using a risk-based model leveraging our work force, processes, and technologies. We support taking stock of and improving the management, handling, and protection of our data inventories and will provide the necessary tools and solutions to identify, prioritize, and mitigate cybersecurity risks against this data an ongoing basis.

title: Do the Right Things the Right Way

content.brief: Best practices bring policy compliance, but policy compliance does not always deliver best practices. We will reduce our cyber risk exposure by implementing cybersecurity best practices across all our activities, from training to daily operations. We identify areas of government-wide strength and weaknesses through our intensive engagement with Federal agencies, and through our efforts to track the right metrics and drive the right behaviors in reporting. We identify common challenges and share what we have learned has worked well amongst Federal agencies so that together we can present a united front in strengthening our collective security. We will foster an environment where our people have the right resources and training to do the right things the right way to achieve our goal. We will keep our people and systems current with the latest training, system patches, and architectures. We will continuously test and audit the effectiveness of our processes, technical activities, and training. We will engage with agencies on their understanding of threats, and the response to incidents, and leverage specialized teams to hunt for unauthorized activities on our networks.

The most successful organizations are the ones who are constantly looking to get better. We will foster a culture where innovation in funding models, service delivery models, processes, and technology is encouraged and rewarded. We will promote investment approaches for new processes and technology that align mission and risk management. We will prioritize spending in the development of more secure and efficient technology solutions over maintaining legacy IT. We will establish new approaches to cybersecurity service delivery, including a centralized IT network. We will develop methods for modernizing the authorization processes for services, including automating testing of security controls, and facilitate efforts to rapidly deploy emerging technologies throughout the government. We will measure our progress through value-added metrics that demonstrate return on investment, risk measures, and productivity.

Username and password is not enough to keep your accounts secure – the ‘Lock Down Your Login’ PSA campaign suggests using using strong authentication to help prevent unauthorized access to your accounts and information.

If you believe you or your organization have been the victim of a cybersecurity incident, defined as a violation or imminent threat of violation of computer security policies, acceptable use policies, or standard security practices, please report the incident to National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center (NCCIC) through this reporting form.
If you believe you are a victim of identity theft, report it to the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) here, and find out what steps you can take to recover.

Phishing is defined as an attempt by an individual or group to solicit personal information from unsuspecting users by employing social engineering techniques, typically via emails containing links to fraudulent websites. Follow the instructions found here to submit these email messages to United States Computer Emergency Readiness Team (US-CERT) to help others avoid becoming victims of phishing scams.

If you have been the victim of ransomware, internet fraud, or other cybercrime, call your local law enforcement personnel and file a complaint with the Internet Crime Complaint Center (IC3) through this form.

Ready.gov is a national PSA designed to educate and empower Americans to prepare for and respond to emergencies. This resource includes information on what to do before, during, and after a cyber attack.

Pursuant to the Federal Information Security Management Act (FISMA), each federal agency is required to notify and consult with US-CERT regarding information security incidents involving the information and information systems. Guidance for these notifications can be found here.

title: NIST Computer Security Incident Handling Guide

content.brief: Recommendations of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) assisting organizations in establishing computer security incident response capabilities and handling incidents efficiently and effectively. This publication provides guidelines for incident handling, particularly for analyzing incident-related data and determining the appropriate response to each incident.

title: Free Security Check Ups and Tools

content.brief: Many computer security vendors offer free computer security checks for your computer. This resource includes links to free virus scans, checkups, and other tools to help keep you safe.

The CISO Council seeks to improve and enhance the cybersecurity posture of the United States by providing a government-wide forum that:

  • promotes the identification, development, and promotion of best practices;
  • promotes shared situational awareness and threat identification;
  • develops and promulgates information security policy;
  • improves strategic hiring and training of cybersecurity professionals, encourages fielding of shared services; and
  • serves as a professional development forum for cybersecurity professionals.

Performance.gov is a window to the Administration’s efforts to deliver a more effective, smarter, and leaner government. The site gives the public, agencies, members of Congress, and the media a view of progress underway in cutting waste, streamlining government, and improving performance. The link below directs to the Cybersecurity section of the site, where metrics on agency performance can be viewed.

Improve cybersecurity performance through ongoing awareness of information security, vulnerabilities, and threats impacting the operating information environment, ensuring that only authorized users have access to resources and information; and the implementation of technologies and processes that reduce the risk of malware.

title: Make Informed Cyber Risk Decisions at the Right Level

content.brief: In the past, most cybersecurity decisions were made in the server room. Today’s environment calls for informed decisions to be made at the right level based on a clearly articulated risk management construct. We will ensure that agencies clearly outline incident response roles and responsibilities for their personnel during a cybersecurity incident, so that issues are brought to the attention of both executive and cybersecurity management in a timely manner. We will continue to measure progress through targeted metrics that provide visibility into risk exposure and drive decisions, and ensure that cyber risk management is integrated into planning, programming, and budgetary activities across the government.

In 2016 we released the first ever Federal Cybersecurity Workforce Strategy directing a series of actions to identify, recruit, develop, retain, and expand the pipeline of the best, brightest, and most diverse cybersecurity talent for Federal service and for our Nation. The strategy brings all levels of government together with private industry, academia, international partners, and the public, to raise the level of cybersecurity in both the public and private sectors; deter and disrupt adversary activities in cyberspace; improve capabilities for incident response and resilience; and enact legislation to both incentivize and remove legal barriers to cybersecurity threat information-sharing among private entities and between the private sector and the Government.
